726AF709AE364009A928085405AA1F70.description: Appreciate the benefits afforded to the modern world by ideas and technologies of past societies.

C8EE4ABD154B4081A854361F016D4960.description: Appreciate the ideas and technologies of early societies.

C18E6B2559FA4A9DA699029F188EEE80.description: Give examples of the continuing influence of ideas and technologies of past societies.

0D18592F1833406EADA6719B1E58FC97.description: Describe the impact of the Industrial Revolution on individuals and societies. Examples: work and living conditions, urbanization, education.

72666DE8EC81423DAE1C90DFC1BBF906.description: Describe the impact of advances in science and technology on societies from the fifteenth to nineteenth centuries. Examples: printing press, compass, telescope, guns, steam engine.

D45D9F7916584E23A5ED734CA456A283.description: Describe the impact of technological developments from the fifth to fifteenth centuries. Examples: wind power, gunpowder, stirrups, catapults, longbows, armour.

6BF4818567784F40B0ED84D862C9554C.description: Identify how work and education were organized in medieval Europe. Examples: guilds and apprenticeships, universities, military training, religious training.

ADD39E265D3D49599164EE6C0EF79E0E.description: Describe technologies and achievements in ancient Greece and Rome. Examples: architecture, transportation, weapons, aqueducts.

DA39B8E20C3F406799DF0C439D3138FF.description: Describe the influence of trade on the exchange of ideas within the Roman Empire and between Rome and other places in the world.

0745695795324E04814EC36B64691408.description:
Describe technologies and tools in an early
society of Mesopotamia, Egypt, or the Indus
Valley.
Examples: animal and crop domestication,
irrigation, construction, weapons,
transportation.

8D6170EB9D314EDAADC044A7EE379617.description: Appreciate the benefits of citizenship within a democracy.

4B5861C0A058462B8D281AAF96062286.description: Locate on a map and describe the nature of the Ottoman Empire and its expansion into the Middle East, North Africa, India, and Europe from the fourteenth to sixteenth centuries.

6F7C055D54024940AE6840B3D68AD445.description: Describe the influence of the Catholic Church in medieval Europe. Examples: education, art, political and social stability, suppression of ideas, attitudes to other faiths.

485AE1C4346044E399099ABE562F3F1A.description: Locate on a map and describe the expansion of the Mongol Empire into China, Europe, and the Middle East in the thirteenth century.

79005446ACD2409D92199D1CEBBA44FE.description: Locate on a map and describe the impact of the Viking invasions on Europe from the ninth to twelfth centuries.

343C2F46B7864DD78D3792994BA34FAB.description: Locate on a map and describe the Arab conquests in the Middle East, North Africa, India, and southern Europe in the seventh and eighth centuries.

AD98BF682CA545F787F730CB873A894B.description: Describe the nature of war and territorial expansion in the Roman Empire.

6C42047C24104DA38B69FF87011F8C98.description: Describe structures of governance in ancient Rome.

891A8E5E5D3447398A0B85FED48B8E13.description: Identify factors that influenced the rise and decline of ancient Greece and Rome.

25F00544FD234BA9B5372F4B07EA912E.description:
Describe governance in an early society of
Mesopotamia, Egypt, or the Indus Valley.
Examples: military organization, political
structures.

F043CB67BD024995B73D04DF09172E04.description: Appreciate the importance of world history in understanding the contemporary world.

4D1E82A8AAC547CEBD2531681505FB1A.description: Appreciate the enduring qualities of art, architecture, literature, and science of the fifth to fifteenth centuries.

F5FF4B799B444D579776B27A7E16AF21.description: Explain the motivations for and the impact of global exploration and territorial expansion from the fifteenth to eighteenth centuries.

994C88EB4F954BBD95C2FA72AC0E1E43.description: Identify major events in Europe, Africa, Asia, Australasia, and the Americas during the fifteenth to eighteenth centuries.

747464D16D494F0AB34E051C592DF00C.description: Give examples of achievements in art, architecture, literature, and science in diverse societies from the fifth to fifteenth centuries.

4D3304195B164635993A4F43C797D6A7.description: Describe the significance of the spread of ideas and technologies between societies from the fifth to fifteenth centuries.

77F863713F014DEB957833AF50429162.description: Identify major events in Europe, the Middle East, Africa, Asia, and the Americas from the fifth to fifteenth centuries.

416628FBCF0043749F78F485DDCBE4DF.description: Identify defining characteristics of the ancient civilizations of China, Greece, Rome, Persia, and the Mayans from 500 BCE to 500 CE.

C24636A9C6824090852FA8E5B0B0F880.description:
Identify defining characteristics of societies in
Mesopotamia, Egypt, the Indus Valley, and
China, from 3500 to 500 BCE.
Examples: location, contributions, beliefs.

761DF10518AA4FCEA937E8D9AEAB6D4F.description: Appreciate the contributions of past societies to the shaping of the modern world.

2EC4D5DA12FF4A5B9C4531D9615D48DE.description: Appreciate the contributions of all societies to the development of the modern world.

3D52000B62B640A3AE6364B2F390C7D5.description: Appreciate stories, legends, and myths of ancient societies as important ways to learn about the past.

34E1DA08FFA542479C44885400D7DB3A.description: Value the study of early societies as a way of understanding contemporary life.

2D0B949D0CB3441DAD3BF04F6CD3DE07.description: Appreciate the historical significance of early societies. Examples: adaptations for survival, enduring human aspirations, origins of social and political structures.

5D889B0865B241F39B15DBD89C399A1F.description: Identify individuals and ideas of the Protestant Reformation during the sixteenth century and describe the historical significance of this movement. Include: shift in power from church to state.

83AA2D0D098D4340BE362C9D5F441F65.description: Identify individuals and ideas of the Renaissance and describe the historical significance of this period.

7ACBD93FA9624AEA93A218EA55153756.description: Describe characteristics of medieval Europe. Examples: feudalism, social and political organization, plagues, medical practices.

964A7A949C2F464EB18AD06B5ECF552D.description: Identify motivations for and consequences of the Crusades. Examples: Peasants’, Nobles’, Kings’, and Children’s Crusades.

BE1AC049014840D780AAED732ABF2688.description: Identify the consequences of the fall of the Western Roman Empire. Examples: the Dark Ages, expansion of Arab- Islamic culture.

088DD9BAA5DD46BC9B12E259994D6917.description: Identify ways in which today’s world has been influenced by the ideas of ancient Greece and Rome. Examples: the arts, philosophy, science, mathematics.

42869D5886C04AC888FF628E79AD8963.description: Describe the impact and significance of the development of writing in an early society of Mesopotamia, Egypt, or the Indus Valley. KH-031 Identify significant people, events, and ideas in ancient Greece and Rome.

0C8DFCB95D10436BA0293A7B881EE4C0.description: Identify people, events, and ideas in an early society of Mesopotamia, Egypt, or the Indus Valley.

9014C9940E3C484E9CA01CCF337F2415.description: Explain the importance of knowing the past and understanding history.

3303AA99FDD3453AA12E6DE31A52E66E.description:
Identify various sources of historical evidence
and information and explain how each
enhances understanding of the past.
Include: archeology, artifacts, literature, art,
music, biographies, journals, photographs,
oral histories.

4E44C5DB0231483C897B679EC99A2A58.description: Appreciate the importance of sustaining the natural environment for future societies.

B263C5DDF996435680BBA9DB9C0AA9E6.description: Illustrate on a world map the voyages of European explorers during the fifteenth to eighteenth centuries. Examples: Christopher Columbus, Giovanni Caboto, Vasco da Gama, Ferdinand Magellan, James Cook.

8D6224B18C7C4A769383135BF8E92E3D.description: Illustrate on a map the expansion of the Roman Empire.

0BF6D6528F404CE69905ED0B6A83637F.description: Give examples of the influence of the natural environment on ways of life in an early society of Mesopotamia, Egypt, or the Indus Valley.

C728DB1DC6A94C2DA1B67289E7AC3C42.description: Locate on a map the major landforms, bodies of water, and population clusters of a society of Mesopotamia, Egypt, or the Indus Valley.

FCFA5B5FD8AF48A197C66315F918D902.description:
Give examples of the influence of the natural
environment on the development of societies.

C1AF8A7AE2F7430A8CE5E811F3A27A9B.description: Value the enduring qualities of art, architecture, ideas, literature, and science of the fifteenth to eighteenth centuries.

A3BEF0CEAF15437294419563493DC8B3.description: Respect others’ ways of life and beliefs.

60211B6C3CBE48A1B965D44B477B213E.description: Appreciate the enduring qualities of the arts, architecture, science, and ideas of ancient Greece and Rome.

DBE7CAFFF5514B11B0265ADDAF158840.description: Be willing to consider differing world views.

74E0EE98B35142498692B26D274B5964.description: Give examples of the impact of interactions between Europeans and indigenous peoples of Africa, Asia, Australasia, and the Americas from the fifteenth to nineteenth centuries. Examples: slavery, diseases, missionaries, intermarriage, adoption of indigenous practices.

590EBF2884E045E5B4A3C7FF464B0161.description: Give examples of the expression of the Renaissance in its art, architecture, philosophy, literature, science, or technology from the fourteenth to sixteenth centuries.

46550085C34B4727B404D228D1D4599F.description: Explain why China may be regarded as one of the most advanced civilizations of the fifth to fifteenth centuries. Examples: science, technology, philosophy, art.

CEE2CB424BC042198866047091D37D27.description: Identify Islamic achievements from the seventh to fifteenth centuries and describe how they influenced other societies. Examples: artistic, literary, intellectual, scientific, religious.

EFDCB10068DA46DEB3B3A9F9FC1AD30E.description: Identify defining characteristics of world religions that emerged in antiquity. Include: Buddhism, Christianity, Confucianism, Hinduism, Judaism.

00BE39FAB6144660933D2B37E735F590.description: Describe the importance of myths in ancient Greek culture.

6C876EFBEC1049DF9614641C8F13EE09.description: Compare and contrast life in Sparta and Athens. Examples: social roles, education, governance, beliefs.

3699BDDF3C224C43A8CAE98377BE5E6F.description: Describe the art, architecture, and science of an early society of Mesopotamia, Egypt, or the Indus Valley.

DFA873005A6747B19232C9711B495C0F.description: Describe life for various groups in an early society of Mesopotamia, Egypt, or the Indus Valley. Examples: priests, scribes, traders, peasants, slaves.

EE601FCE7F224D6CAC458C8DEEF5834C.description: Describe the development of agrarian societies and explain how they differed from hunter- gatherer societies. Examples: food surplus, movement from nomadic to sedentary, division of labour, growth of villages and cities.

370A533C3F184E66855B91EC36B3CE39.description: Identify the characteristics, advantages, and disadvantages of a hunter-gatherer way of life.

DD745EA163624E9C9B30C23B8DEF31DA.description: Relate various stories and theories of the origin and development of human life.

A3BC558BCEB443F38723D8579CBB62A4.description: Describe ways in which societies organize, maintain, and perpetuate themselves. Examples: physical survival, education, culture.

EE337C4772154CC78968B59F8D4BD18D.description: Give reasons why societies may stay the same or change over time. Examples: culture, education, trade, power, war.

73A893503CB54675BC52C2D59D1F756B.description: Compare and contrast the concepts of society and civilization.

7EC54CB4FF39405FBC2953E349A663BC.description: Describe influences that create differences in world views. Examples: culture, time, place, cross-cultural interactions, media, governance.

08499A4CC3A6461C863A4499F889C230.description: Explain the concept of world view.

4138D2FB844741D58B94C25D9C18D8D7.description: Appreciate the struggles of past societies for their importance in shaping the modern world.

0E262553AE564425ADFB3402012BC085.description: Appreciate the struggles of past societies for their importance in shaping the modern world.

26D440D850294E87858337F2D96FE9BA.description: Appreciate the enduring significance of the rule of law.

53A100F9CCB14141B90475B7C8FE4026.description: Appreciate the contributions of ancient Greece to modern concepts of citizenship and democracy.

A923FB3517474DF0830BBB9873ED76CC.description: Identify the origins and significance of the rule of law. Include: transition from absolute monarchy to representative government.

C3F4AD65483A449E9A11A7B8FE523BC3.description: Compare criteria for citizenship and participation in government in ancient Greece and in contemporary Canada.

77902878847B41039D7ED9A13A6FDBCC.description: Describe the rise of democracy in ancient Greece.

5944D348203A458FA2F8EA2E04A3CD3C.description:
Describe the social organization of ancient
Greece.
Examples: classes of citizens, slavery; role
and status of children, women, and men.

26C7AEDA946A4ADB81A08D541751DDE4.description: Articulate their beliefs and perspectives on issues.

DC2EC4705F584FA4AD642F0BB3E76DCB.description: Elicit and clarify questions and ideas in discussions.

2B42E764958B4D57BBF2B2ABF51DDEE9.description: Present information and ideas orally, visually, concretely, or electronically.

30A3C36A4A9C4B6F8C70A863A1EF1FCB.description: Persuasively express differing viewpoints regarding an issue.

C7E97B7C9B4246FDAC309F42CC60484A.description: Use language that is respectful of human diversity.

A4D4C77E39CF4E5288EE9B2CBB81FD26.description:
Listen to others to understand their
perspectives.

4E75A205538544E587A6C322F2A388E9.description: Analyze prejudice, racism, stereotyping, or other forms of bias in the media and other information sources.

8679E722047549739CD1779AE011F674.description: Recognize that interpretations of history are subject to change as new information is uncovered or acknowledged.

F83B83D5D83D4214BF902D90A2E7E8BB.description: Interpret information and ideas in a variety of media. Examples: art, music, historical fiction, drama, primary sources.

42001652746F4D1D89BFD6E45D875CAB.description: Compare diverse perspectives in the media and other information sources.

9C66466BFF8145CFAD02C626B086A762.description: Compare differing accounts of historical events.

EBB82CF2BB554C7F9D2CCD1B33A59715.description: Assess the validity of information sources. Examples: purpose, context, authenticity, origin, objectivity, evidence, reliability...

B0BF4C9C34B943FDA05792259AF0235C.description: Observe and analyze material and visual evidence for research. Examples: artifacts, photographs, works of art.

E76D78A2840D44C1A5CACA91E2838E11.description: Distinguish fact from opinion and interpretation.

EEBC26B8380B4839B5BFDB3E44CD05DB.description: Evaluate personal assumptions based on new information and ideas.

AAD5713697474CF6849471626127B495.description: Draw conclusions based on research and evidence.

6CBE8288BEBD407296C71B8BC4F4298D.description: Consider the context of events, accounts, ideas, and interpretations.

94415C56B29F4225AC52F2194E06961B.description:
Plan topics, goals, and methods for historical
inquiry and research.

270D7642775341D884AFB62E453F8D77.description: Orient themselves by observing the landscape, using traditional knowledge, or using a compass or other tools and technologies.

E212942570444F06970D133D81A49ED3.description: Use traditional knowledge to read the land.

F7AAE390302F4CBDA25A4271405EDF50.description: Use latitude and longitude to locate and describe places on maps and globes.

A84D7B9D4ACE4B75B18B794FC18876E2.description: Select, use, and interpret various types of maps for specific purposes. Examples: historical maps and atlases.

56FD603081794B0D9DFEC38245E2A730.description: Construct maps that include a title, legend, compass rose, scale, and latitude and longitude.

EB14B268AE2040458B84671265632371.description: Create timelines and other visual organizers to sequence and represent historical periods, figures, relationships, or chronological events.

DEA93B9016554D0A8AD5C4B75B43A2F3.description: Select and use appropriate tools and technologies to accomplish tasks.

59AB5EFF992B43A68467F35A5BB29580.description: Interpret primary and secondary information sources for research.

A8404BE866E14D048725FD5904C18F98.description: Organize and record information in a variety of formats and reference sources appropriately. Examples: maps, charts, outlines, concept maps.

BD089EDF98364AF983D3FFB954748B16.description:
Select information from a variety of oral,
visual, material, print, or electronic sources.
Examples: maps, atlases, art, songs, artifacts,
narratives, legends, biographies, historical
fiction.

0C846170F562486795825F1ACA86560C.description: Treat places and objects of historical significance with respect. Examples: burial grounds, memorials, artifacts.Comments: Some sacred places may not be known publicly as sacred places.

00800685E974443C8C7F8B81CB97E975.description: Recognize bias and discrimination and propose solutions. Examples: racism, ageism, heterosexism.

107BB36A1F6049C8974D2B0DED685181.description: Negotiate constructively with others to build consensus and solve problems.

0ACF1C138362436481669F6C95C89695.description: Make decisions that reflect the principles of sustainable development.

EC1E428F3E544726BD62A48778DC503C.description: Make decisions that reflect fairness and equality in their interactions with others.

28A2E0C0B8524B8998AD22AA52D908DE.description: Use a variety of strategies to resolve conflicts peacefully and fairly. Examples: clarification, negotiation, compromise.

5EC7B07A2F5B43E4BF758541D8630E04.description:
Collaborate with others to establish and carry
out group goals and responsibilities.
